answer_html: The only way that this integral has value 1 is when k = 3.
answer_latex:
The only way that this integral has value 1 is when \textbf{\emph{k} =
3}.
hints_html:
For \(f\) to be a probability density function it needs to satisfy two conditions:

  • \(f\)(x) \(\geq\) 0 for all x,

  • \(\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx = 1.\)

Choose k such that both conditions are fulfilled.

The formula for the mean \(\mu\) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \mu = \int_{-\infty}^\infty xf(x)\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

The median m is that number which satisfies

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx = \frac12 = \int_m^\infty f(x)\,dx.\end{aligned}\]
hints_latex:
For $f$ to be a probability density function it needs to satisfy two
conditions:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $f$(x) $\geq$ 0 for all \emph{x},
\item
  $\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx = 1.$
\end{itemize}

Choose \emph{k} such that both conditions are fulfilled.
hints_raw:
For &fnof; to be a probability density function it needs to satisfy two conditions:

* &fnof;(x) &ge; 0 for all ''x'',
* <math> \int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx = 1. </math>

Choose ''k'' such that both conditions are fulfilled.
The formula for the mean <math>\mu</math> is given by

:<math>\displaystyle \mu = \int_{-\infty}^\infty xf(x)\,dx. </math>
The median ''m'' is that number which satisfies

:<math> \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx = \frac12 = \int_m^\infty f(x)\,dx. </math>
sols_html:
(a) Using hint 1 we see that k needs to be a positive constant. We can calculate k directly by integrating:

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx &= \int_{-\infty}^0 0\,dx + \int_0^1 kx(1-x^4)\,dx + \int_1^\infty 0\,dx \\ &= k \int_0^1 (x-x^5)\,dx \\ &= k\left.\left(\frac{x^2}2-\frac{x^6}6\right)\right|_0^1 \\ &= k \left(\frac12 - \frac16\right) \\ &= \frac{k}3.\end{aligned}\]

The only way that this integral has value 1 is when k = 3.

(b) Using the second hint and the fact that k = 3 the calculation is straight forward

\[\begin{aligned} \mu &= \int_{-\infty}^\infty xf(x)\,dx \\ &= \int_0^1 (x)3x(1-x^4)\,dx \\ &= 3\int_0^1 (x^2-x^6)\,dx \\ &= 3\left.\left(\frac{x^3}3 - \frac{x^7}7\right)\right|_0^1 \\ &= 3\left(\frac13 - \frac17\right) \\ &= \frac47.\end{aligned}\]

(c) Following the third hint we need to find that value m which satisfies

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx = \frac12 = \int_m^\infty f(x)\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

Since \(\int_{-\infty}^0 f(x)\,dx = 0 = \int_1^\infty f(x)\,dx\) it is clear that m needs to be a number between 0 and 1. Therefore the algebraic equation that m satisfies is the following;

\[\begin{aligned} \frac12 &= \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx \\ &= \int_0^m 3x(1-x^4)\,dx \\ &= 3\left.\left(\frac{x^2}2 - \frac{x^6}6\right)\right|_0^m \\ &= 3\left(\frac{m^2}2 - \frac{m^6}6\right).\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
\textbf{(a)} Using hint 1 we see that \emph{k} needs to be a positive
constant. We can calculate \emph{k} directly by integrating:

\begin{align*}
\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx &= \int_{-\infty}^0 0\,dx + \int_0^1 kx(1-x^4)\,dx + \int_1^\infty 0\,dx \\
&= k \int_0^1 (x-x^5)\,dx \\
&= k\left.\left(\frac{x^2}2-\frac{x^6}6\right)\right|_0^1 \\
&= k \left(\frac12 - \frac16\right) \\
&= \frac{k}3.
\end{align*}

The only way that this integral has value 1 is when \textbf{\emph{k} =
3}.

\textbf{(b)} Using the second hint and the fact that \emph{k} = 3 the
calculation is straight forward

\begin{align*}
\mu &= \int_{-\infty}^\infty xf(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^1 (x)3x(1-x^4)\,dx \\
&= 3\int_0^1 (x^2-x^6)\,dx \\
&= 3\left.\left(\frac{x^3}3 - \frac{x^7}7\right)\right|_0^1 \\
&= 3\left(\frac13 - \frac17\right) \\
&= \frac47.
\end{align*}

'''(a)''' Using hint 1 we see that ''k'' needs to be a positive constant. We can calculate ''k'' directly by integrating:

:<math> \begin{align}
\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx &= \int_{-\infty}^0 0\,dx + \int_0^1 kx(1-x^4)\,dx + \int_1^\infty 0\,dx \\
&= k \int_0^1 (x-x^5)\,dx \\
&= k\left.\left(\frac{x^2}2-\frac{x^6}6\right)\right|_0^1 \\
&= k \left(\frac12 - \frac16\right) \\
&= \frac{k}3.
\end{align}
</math>

The only way that this integral has value 1 is when '''''k'' = 3'''.
'''(b)''' Using the second hint and the fact that ''k'' = 3 the calculation is straight forward

:<math> \begin{align}
\mu &= \int_{-\infty}^\infty xf(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^1 (x)3x(1-x^4)\,dx \\
&= 3 \int_0^1 (x^2-x^6)\,dx \\
&= 3\left.\left(\frac{x^3}3 - \frac{x^7}7\right)\right|_0^1 \\
&= 3\left(\frac13 - \frac17\right) \\
&= \frac47.
\end{align}
</math>
'''(c)''' Following the third hint we need to find that value ''m'' which satisfies

:<math> \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx = \frac12 = \int_m^\infty f(x)\,dx. </math>

Since <math> \int_{-\infty}^0 f(x)\,dx = 0 = \int_1^\infty f(x)\,dx </math> it is clear that ''m'' needs to be a number between 0 and 1. Therefore the algebraic equation that ''m'' satisfies is the following;

:<math> \begin{align}
\frac12 &= \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^m 3x(1-x^4)\,dx \\
&= 3\left.\left(\frac{x^2}2 - \frac{x^6}6\right)\right|_0^m \\
&= 3\left(\frac{m^2}2 - \frac{m^6}6\right).
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Let X be a random variable with probability density function:

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \begin{cases} kx(1-x^4) & \text{ if } 0 \leq x \leq 1,\\ 0 & \text{ if } x < 0 \text{ or } x > 1. \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

(a) Find the value of k.

(b) Find the mean \(\mu\).

(c) Find an algebraic equation satisfied by the median m.
statement_raw:
Let ''X'' be a random variable with probability density function:

:<math>f(x) = \begin{cases} kx(1-x^4) & \text{ if } 0 \leq x \leq 1,\\ 0 & \text{ if } x < 0 \text{ or } x > 1. \end{cases}</math>

(a) Find the value of ''k''.

(b) Find the mean <math>\mu</math>.

(c) Find an algebraic equation satisfied by the median ''m''.
